case_name: Smt. Harnam Kaur v. Mangal Singh, Amer Singh, Santa Singh and Ishar Singh

facts.text: The suit was for possession of some land which was admittedly owned at one time by one Labhu.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit brought for possession of some land which was admittedly owned at one time by one Labhu.

facts.text: Labhu died in the year 1917.

anchor.surface_text: Labhu died in the year 1917 and, on his death his widow, Smt. Harnam Kaur, who filed the suit as plaintiff, came into possession of the land.

facts.text: On Labhu's death, his widow Smt. Harnam Kaur came into possession of the land.

anchor.surface_text: Labhu died in the year 1917 and, on his death his widow, Smt. Harnam Kaur, who filed the suit as plaintiff, came into possession of the land.

facts.text: Smt. Harnam Kaur continued in possession of the land until the year 1954.

anchor.surface_text: She companytinued in possession of the land until the year 1954 when, on an application made by the companylaterals of Labhu, the Naib Tehsildar, by his order dated 26th June, 1954, effected mutation in favour of these companylaterals.

facts.text: Naib Tehsildar by order dated 26th June 1954 effected mutation in favour of collaterals defendants 1 to 4: Mangal Singh, Amer Singh, Santa Singh and Ishar Singh.

anchor.surface_text: She companytinued in possession of the land until the year 1954 when, on an application made by the companylaterals of Labhu, the Naib Tehsildar, by his order dated 26th June, 1954, effected mutation in favour of these companylaterals. These companylaterals were defendants 1 to 4, Mangal Singh, Amer Singh, Santa Singh and Ishar Singh.

facts.text: Defendants 1 to 4 dispossessed Smt. Harnam Kaur on the basis of Naib Tehsildar order.

anchor.surface_text: These companylaterals, on the basis of the order of the Naib Tehsildar, dispossessed Smt. Harnam Kaur.

facts.text: Harnam Kaur's appeal against Naib Tehsildar order was dismissed by the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: Harnam Kaurs appeal against the order of the Naib Tehsildar was dismissed by the Collector.

facts.text: Defendants claimed Smt. Harnam Kaur entered into karewa marriage with Ishar Singh (defendant No. 4).

anchor.surface_text: The claim of these companylaterals was that Smt. Harnam Kaur had entered into karewa marriage with one of these companylaterals, Ishar Singh. defendant No. 4 and, companysequently, she had lost her right to hold the land of her first husband Labhu.

facts.text: Smt. Harnam Kaur denied karewa marriage with Ishar Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Smt. Harnam Kaur denied that she had entered into any karewa marriage with Ishar Singh and, on the basis of this denial, instituted the suit claiming possession of that land.

facts.text: Suit instituted by Smt. Harnam Kaur on 1st March 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This suit was instituted on 1st March, 1956.

facts.text: Hindu Succession Act 1956 came into force on 17th June 1956.

anchor.surface_text: After the institution of the suit, the Hindu Succession Act, 1956  No. 30 of 1956  hereinafter referred to as the Act came into force on 17th June, 1956.

facts.text: Suit was pending when Act came into force.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was, at that time, pending and it companytinued to remain pending until the year 1958 when Smt. Harnam Kaur died.

facts.text: Smt. Harnam Kaur died in 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was, at that time, pending and it companytinued to remain pending until the year 1958 when Smt. Harnam Kaur died.

facts.text: Smt. Rattno applied to be substituted as plaintiff as legal representative of Smt. Harnam Kaur; application allowed though opposed by defendants 1 to 3.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, Smt. Rattno applied to be substituted as plaintiff in place of Smt. Harnam Kaur as her legal representative. This application was allowed,, though it was opposed by defendants 1 to 3.

facts.text: Trial court held Smt. Harnam Kaur contracted karewa marriage with Ishar Singh and lost rights; dispossessed before Act, s.14 not apply; suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that Smt. Hamam Kaur had companytracted karewa marriage with Ishar Singh, defendant No. 4, and had lost her rights. The further finding of the trial companyrt was that Smt. Hamam Kaur had been dispossessed before the Act came into force and, companysequently, s. 14 of the Act did number apply, with the result that Smt. Rattno companyld number claim succession to Smt. Hamam Kaur under that provision of law. On these findings, the trial companyrt dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Additional District Judge Patiala (first appellate) held no karewa marriage; s.14 applicable as land possessed by Harnam Kaur; decreed suit against defendants 1-3.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Additional District Judge, Patiala, recorded the finding that Smt. Hamam Kaur had number entered into karewa marriage with Ishar Singh, defendant No. 4, and, further, that s. 14 of the Act was applicable to the present case, as the land in suit was possessed by Smt. Harnam Kaur so as to make her full owner of this land under that provision of law. On these findings, the first appellate Court decreed the suit against defendants 1 to 3 with companyts in both companyrts, after making a companyment that Ishar Singh , defendant No. 4, was a profoma defendant.

facts.text: Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1958 of 1959 by judgment dated January 3, 1962 dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 3, 1962 of the Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1958 of 1959.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 51 of 1964 by special leave to Supreme Court by defendants 1-3.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 51 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 3, 1962 of the Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1958 of 1959.

facts.text: Defendant No. 4 Ishar Singh admitted claim of plaintiff, denied dispossession and karewa marriage.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant No. 4, however, admitted the claim of Smt. Hamarn Kaur in his written statement, denied that he had dispossessed her and also denied the allegation of her karewa marriage with him.

facts.text: During pendency of Supreme Court appeal, one defendant-appellant died and legal representatives brought on record.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this appeal, one of the defendants- appellants died and his legal representatives were brought on the record as appellants.

facts.text: Smt. Rattno died and her legal representatives impleaded as respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Smt. Rattno also died and her legal representatives were impleaded as respondents.

facts.text: Ishar Singh (defendant No. 4) died; application to bring his LRs on record dismissed by Supreme Court order dated 14th September 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Further, Ishar Singh,. defendant No. 4, who was a respondent in this appeal, also died. The application to bring his legal representatives on record was dismissed by the order of this Court dated 14th September, 1965 in Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 1589 of 1965.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected preliminary objection on abatement due to failure to implead LRs of Ishar Singh.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this order, a preliminary objection was raised... The preliminary objection, therefore, fails and is rejected.

facts.text: First appellate court finding that no karewa marriage proved, binding on High Court and Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellate Court, which was the final Court for deciding question of fact, clearly recorded a finding that the karewa marriage alleged... was number proved. That finding of fact was binding on the High Court and was rightly accepted by it.

facts.text: Smt. Harnam Kaur dispossessed by defendants 1 to 3 in 1954 illegally.

anchor.surface_text: On this finding, it has to be held that the rights to the land... were number lost by her until her death, and that her dispossession by defendants 1 to 3 in the year 1954 was illegal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that property was possessed by Smt. Harnam Kaur as per s.14(1) even after dispossession.

anchor.surface_text: On the language of s. 14 1 , therefore, we hold that this prorovision will become applicable to any property which is owned by a female Hindu, even though she is number in actual, physical or companystructive possession of that property.

facts.text: No dispute that if s.14 applies, rights pass to Smt. Rattno and then present respondents.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that there was numberdispute in the High Court, number was it disputed before us that, if it be held that S. 14 of the Act had become applicable... her rights would pass on her death to Smt. Rattno and, subsequently, on the latters death, to the present respondents in this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court decision on merits.

anchor.surface_text: On merits, we are of the opinion that the decision given by the High Court against the defendant-appellants must be upheld.

facts.text: Ishar Singh treated as pro forma defendant; suit decreed only against 1-3.

anchor.surface_text: decreed the suit against defendants 1 to 3... treating Ishar Singh as a profoma defendant.

facts.text: Smt. Harnam Kaur was out of actual possession at death in 1958, suit pending.

anchor.surface_text: when Smt. Hamam Kaur died, she was number in actual possession of this land. She had been dispossessed in the year 1954 and, at the time of her death in 1958, this suit instituted by her for possession of that land was still pending.

concepts.unlisted_description: Any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the commencement of this Act, shall be held by her as full owner thereof and not as a limited owner.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14(1) of the Act is as follows: 14.(1) Any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the commencement of this Act, shall be held by her as full owner thereof and not as a limited owner. Explanation.—In this sub-section, “property” includes both movable and immovable property

concepts.unlisted_description: Quoted in full with Explanation defining property and modes of acquisition including stridhana.

anchor.surface_text: On the language of s. 14(1), therefore, we hold that this provision will become applicable to any property which is owned by a female Hindu, even though she is not in actual, physical or constructive possession of that property.

concepts.interpretation: Interpreted 'possessed by' broadly to include state of ownership even without actual or constructive possession if title exists; applies despite dispossession by trespasser.

issues.text: Whether the appeal had abated on account of the failure of the appellants to implead the legal representatives of Ishar Singh respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this order, a preliminary objection was raised at the time of hearing of this appeal by learned counsel for the respondents, who had been impleaded as legal representatives of Smt. Rattno, that the appeal had abated on account of the failure of the appellants to implead the legal representatives of Ishar Singh respondent.

issues.text: Whether Smt. Harnam Kaur had entered into a karewa marriage with Ishar Singh, defendant No. 4, so as to lose her right to the disputed land as widow of the previous male owner, Labhu.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, two main questions came up for decision by the trial court. The first question was whether Smt. Hamam Kaur had entered into a karewa marriage with Ishar Singh, defendant No. 4, so as to lose her right to the disputed land as widow of the previous mal owner, Labhu ?

issues.text: Whether Smt. Rattno, who was substituted as the legal representative of Smt. Harnam Kaur, was entitled to succeed to the property of Smt. Harnam Kaur.

anchor.surface_text: The second question that arose was whether Smt. Rattno, who was substituted as the legal representative of Smt. Hamam Kaur, was entitled to succeed to the property of Smt. Hamam Kaur ? This second question depended on whether Smt. Harnam Kaur had, or had not, become full owner of the land under S. 14 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether it can be held that this property was possessed by Smt. Harnam Kaur as envisaged by S. 14 of the Act, so that she became full owner of this land.

anchor.surface_text: The only question for decision in this appeal, therefore, is whether it can be held that this property was possessed by Smt. Harnam Kaur as envisaged by S. 14 of the Act, so that she became full owner of this land.

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature used 'possessed by' not 'in possession of' to enlarge scope.

arguments.claim: S.14(1) applies to property possessed/owned by female Hindu even without actual, physical or constructive possession.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14(1) of the Act is as follows: 14.(1) Any property possessed by a female Hindu... On the language of s. 14(1), therefore, we hold that this provision will become applicable to any property which is owned by a female Hindu, even though she is not in actual, physical or constructive possession of that property.

arguments.claim: 'Possessed by' includes possession in law, state of owning, even if not entered into land.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the expression used in s. 14(1) of the Act was intended to cover cases of possession in law also, where lands may have descended to a female Hindu and she has not actually entered into them... citing Stroud and Wharton definitions.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Gummalpura supports broad meaning of 'possessed' as state of owning.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14(1) came up for interpretation... the earliest case is that of Gummalpura Taggina Matada Kotturuswami... possessed in s. 14 is used in a broad sense and, in the context, means the state of owning or having in ones hand or power.

arguments.claim: Appellants' interpretation of Gummalpura requiring possession at commencement rejected.

arguments.claim: In alienation cases without legal necessity, widow not possessed as parted with rights.

anchor.surface_text: The next case... Brahmdeo Singh... held that the sale-deeds were not for legal necessity... alienation... binding on her... she had no longer any legal right left.

arguments.claim: S.14 converts limited estate to absolute even if only right declared by preliminary decree, without possession.

anchor.surface_text: The third case... S. S. Munna Lal... widow died while partition suit pending... held possessed despite no actual possession.

arguments.claim: S.14 requires title/ownership, not mere possession by trespasser.

anchor.surface_text: The last case... Eramma Veerupana... property possessed... to which she has acquired some kind of title... cannot validate illegal possession of trespasser.

arguments.claim: High Court cases on alienation not applicable to trespasser dispossession.

anchor.surface_text: On the interpretation... it does not appear to be necessary... to refer to the decisions of the various High Courts... All these were cases relating to situations where the widow had made some alienation

holdings.text: The appeal had not abated on account of the failure of the appellants to implead the legal representatives of Ishar Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, appears that, on the pleadings of parties and the nature of the dispute that came to be settled by the lower courts, it cannot be held that this appeal must abate as a whole, or must fail because of its abatement against Ishar Singh on his death. We have already mentioned that, though the plaintiff, Smt. Harnam Kaur, had come forward with the allegation that she had been dispossessed by all the four defendants 1 to 4, Ishar Singh, defendant No. 4, in his written statement, repudiated this claim.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ishar Singh was a pro forma defendant with no decree against him; he supported plaintiff; dispute confined to main parties (plaintiff vs defendants 1-3).

holdings.text: The finding that no karewa marriage was proved between Smt. Harnam Kaur and Ishar Singh is binding on the High Court and this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellate Court, which was the final Court for deciding question of fact, clearly recorded a finding that the karewa marriage alleged to have been entered into by the plaintiff, Smt. Harnam Kaur, with Ishar Singh, defendant No. 4, was not proved. That finding of fact was binding on the High Court and was rightly accepted by it. It is no longer open to the appellants to challenge that finding of fact in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First appellate court is final fact-finding court; finding accepted by High Court.

holdings.text: Smt. Harnam Kaur did not lose her rights to the land until her death; her dispossession by defendants 1 to 3 in 1954 was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: On this finding, it has to be held that the rights to the land, to which Smt. Harnam Kaur had succeeded as widow of Labhu, were not lost by her until her death, and that her dispossession by defendants 1 to 3 in the year 1954 was illegal. They had no right to this land in preference to Smt. Harnam Kaur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from no karewa marriage; collaterals had no superior right.

holdings.text: Section 14(1) of the Hindu Succession Act applies to any property owned by a female Hindu even if she is not in actual, physical or constructive possession.

anchor.surface_text: On the language of s. 14(1), therefore, we hold that this provision will become applicable to any property which is owned by a female Hindu, even though she is not in actual, physical or constructive possession of that property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation ('possessed by' broader than 'in possession of'); dictionary definitions (Stroud, Wharton); follows precedents (Gummalpura, Munna Lal, Eramma); distinguishes alienation cases.

holdings.text: The disputed property was possessed by Smt. Harnam Kaur as envisaged by s.14(1) when she died in 1958; she became full owner; rights passed to Smt. Rattno and then to present respondents.

anchor.surface_text: On the interpretation of S. 14(1) of the Act that we have accepted above, it must be held that the property involved in the present suit was possessed by Smt. Harnam Kaur when she died in the year 1958 and, consequently, Smt. Rattno and, after her, the present respondents must be deemed to have succeeded to those rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies broad interpretation of 'possessed by' to facts: widow owned property despite trespasser dispossession; undisputed that full ownership leads to succession under ss.15-16.

holdings.text: The decision of the High Court against the defendant-appellants must be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: On merits, we are of the opinion that the decision given by the High Court against the defendant-appellants must be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower courts on facts and law.

precedents.citation: Gummalpura Taggina Matada Kotturuswami v. Setra Veeravva and others 1

anchor.surface_text: Gummalpura Taggina Matada Kotturuswami v. Setra Veeravva and others 1 . Gaddam Veerayya  2  , and numbericed the fact that in that case it was held that the word possessed is used in s. 14 in a broad sense and, in the companytext, possession means the state of owning or having in ones bands or power.

precedents.cited_holding: even if a trespasser were in possession of the land belonging to a female owner, it might conceivably be regarded as being in possession of the female owner, provided the trespasser had not perfected his title

precedents.citation: Brahmdeo Singh and Another v. Deomani Missir and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Brahmdeo Singh and Another v. Deomani Missir and Others 1  In that case, the female Hindu, who had succeeded to the property as the widow of her husband, Ramdeo Singh, had transferred the property under two sale-deeds. It was held that the sale-deeds were number for legal necessity and the question arose whether, in those circumstances, when the Act came into force, it companyld be held that the widow was possessed of that property.

precedents.cited_proposition: property alienated by widow without legal necessity is not possessed by her under S.14(1)
precedents.cited_holding: an alienation made by a widow... without legal necessity... is... binding on her so as to pass her own interest i.e. life interest to the alienee

anchor.surface_text: Gummalapura Taggina Matada Kotturuswami 2  held that the companyflict of judicial opinion -on this question had already been resolved in that earlier case, where the Court had observed The provisions in S. 14 of the Act were number intended to benefit alienees who, with their eyes open, purchased the property from a limited owner without justifying necessity before the Act came into force and at a time when the vendor had only a limited interest of a Hindu woman.

precedents.case_name: Gummalpura Taggina Matada Kotturuswami v. Setra Veeravva
precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of S.14 not intended to benefit alienees from limited owner without necessity
precedents.cited_holding: The provisions in S. 14 of the Act were not intended to benefit alienees who... purchased... without justifying necessity

precedents.citation: S. S. Minna Lal v. S. S. Rajkumar and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: S. S. Minna Lal v. S. S. Rajkumar and Others 1 . In that case, a Digamber Jain of the Porwal sect died in 1934 leaving behind his widow, his son and three grand-sons. His son died in 1939. In 1952, a son of one of the grandsons filed a suit for partition of the joint family properties, while the widow was still alive.

precedents.case_name: S. S. Minna Lal v. S. S. Rajkumar
precedents.cited_proposition: right declared under preliminary decree for partition is property possessed by Hindu female under S.14(1) even without actual possession
precedents.cited_holding: the right declared in favour of a Hindu female must also be regarded as property

anchor.surface_text: Eramma Veerupana and Others 1 . That was a companyverse case in which the female Hindu, in fact, did number possess any legal right or title to the property, though she was actually in physical possession of it. It was held The property possessed by a female Hindu, as companytemplated in the section, is clearly property to which she has acquired some kind of title, whether before or after the companymencement of the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: possessed by a female Hindu under S.14(1) requires some title, not mere physical possession as trespasser
precedents.cited_holding: the section cannot be interpreted so as to validate the illegal possession of a female Hindu and it does not confer any title on a mere trespasser

precedents.citation: Sansir Patelin and Another v. Satyabatt Naikani and Another 1

anchor.surface_text: Nathuni Prasad Singh and Another v. Mst. Kachnar Kuer Others 5  and Mst. Mukhtiar Kaur v. Mst. Kartar Kaur and Others 4 . All these were cases relating to situations where the widow had made some alienation of her rights in the property and numbere of them was companycerned with a case where the female Hindu might have been dispossessed by a trespasser. The reasons given by the High Courts in those cases are, therefore, of numberassistance in deciding the applicability of S. 14 1  of the Act to a case of the nature before us.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, appears that, on the pleadings of parties and the nature of the dispute that came to be settled by the lower courts, it cannot be held that this appeal must abate as a whole, or must fail because of its abatement against Ishar Singh on his death. We have already mentioned that, though the plaintiff, Smt. Harnam Kaur, had come forward with the allegation that she had been dispossessed by all the four defendants 1 to 4, Ishar Singh, defendant No. 4, in his written statement, repudiated this claim.
On merits, we are of the opinion that the decision given by the High Court against the defendant-appellants must be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: The first appellate Court, which was the final Court for deciding question of fact, clearly recorded a finding that the karewa marriage alleged to have been entered into by the plaintiff, Smt. Harnam Kaur, with Ishar Singh, defendant No. 4, was not proved. That finding of fact was binding on the High Court and was rightly accepted by it. It is no longer open to the appellants to challenge that finding of fact in this Court.
On merits, we are of the opinion that the decision given by the High Court against the defendant-appellants must be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: On the language of s. 14(1), therefore, we hold that this provision will become applicable to any property which is owned by a female Hindu, even though she is not in actual, physical or constructive possession of that property.
On merits, we are of the opinion that the decision given by the High Court against the defendant-appellants must be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: On the interpretation of S. 14(1) of the Act that we have accepted above, it must be held that the property involved in the present suit was possessed by Smt. Harnam Kaur when she died in the year 1958 and, consequently, Smt. Rattno and, after her, the present respondents must be deemed to have succeeded to those rights.
